I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The Naryn Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Development Program will be financed by 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The program, which will be implemented during 2019–2026, 
aims to enhance inclusive and reliable access to safe water supply and improved sanitation for 
rural communities in Naryn province of the Kyrgyz Republic. The program will contribute to a 
portion of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Strategy for Development of Water Supply 
and Sewerage Systems in Settlements, 2016–2026 to improve access to safe and quality water 
supply and sanitation (WSS) services.1 The Department of Drinking Water Supply and Sewerage 
Development (DDWSSD) under the State Agency for Water Resources will be the executing 
agency and the Community Development and Investment Agency (ARIS) will be the implementing 
agency of the results-based lending (RBL) program. 
 
2.  The RBL program will focus on rural WSS service provision for 43 villages in Naryn 
province. The program outcome will be inclusive and reliable access to safe water supply and 
improved sanitation for rural communities in Naryn province. The program outputs are (i) WSS 
infrastructure  expanded  and  sanitation  solutions  piloted,  and  (ii)  institutional  capacities 
strengthened for enhanced sustainability in the rural water supply services and rural sanitation 
subsector. The RBL program expenditures are estimated to be $32.9 million. ADB will provide a 
loan of $13.7 million from its concessional ordinary capital resources and a grant of $13.7 million 
from its Special Funds resources (Asian Development Fund). 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The government has requested ADB support to help implement the RBL program. While 
the government will procure consulting services to support implementation of the program action 
plan (PAP), additional resources are required to complement the RBL program to assist the 
government in addressing key risks identified during program processing. The scope of the 
transaction advisory technical assistance (TA) was discussed with the DDWSSD during the fact-
finding mission in April 2019.2 
 
4.  The TA will support the effective implementation of both outputs of the RBL and is linked 
with support to output 2 under the program (para. 2). The TA will provide technical advisory 
support services to the DDWSSD and ARIS for strengthening program systems to effectively 
manage  and  implement  the  PAP,  primarily  in  monitoring  and  accurate  reporting  of  the 
achievements  of  disbursement-linked  indicators  (DLIs),  other  indicators,  program  and 
procurement  action  plans,  safeguards,  and  fiduciary  elements.  The  TA  will  also  recruit  a 
consultancy firm to conduct independent evaluation of achievements against the DLIs and targets. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
5.  Output 1: Program systems strengthened to implement the results-based lending 
program. The TA will develop capacity of the DDWSSD and ARIS in complying with the program 
and country system requirements. Key activities include assisting the program implementation

unit in screening projects for safeguard impacts; monitoring environmental and resettlement-
related implementation management plans and social safeguards requirements (if necessary); 
and carrying out related training. The TA consultants will also support ARIS in procurement 
planning and budgeting, strengthening quality of design and construction by (i) preparing an 18-
month procurement plan, (ii) verifying detailed designs, (iii) periodically inspecting construction 
works, and (iv) conducting technical and procurement audits. The TA will also bolster capacity for 
contract  management,  administration,  and  procurement.  Feasibility  studies  and  detailed 
engineering designs will be financed by the RBL and verified by TA consultants to ensure 
compliance with technical standards. A methodology and framework for technical auditing will be 
developed in the first year of RBL program implementation. The TA will also develop capacity of 
the implementing agency to conduct climate change risk assessment for selection of WSS 
development. 
 
6.  Output 2: Monitoring and evaluation system for program indicators improved. This 
output will support crucial program monitoring functions required for timely and effective program 
implementation. The TA will develop the capacity of the DDWSSD and ARIS in tracking (i) the 
indicators in the program design and monitoring framework, and DLIs; (ii) the PAP; and (iii) 
compliance with the RBL program agreement. Key activities include (i) the preparation of results-
based annual work plans and budget in line with the targets in the program results framework; (ii) 
the preparation of annual performance and progress reports; (iii) conduct of annual fiduciary 
reviews and launch of timely actions, if needed; (iv) monitoring of the implementation of the 
financial management action plan; (v) review of financial management reports and audit reports 
with  recommendations  for  corrective  action;  (vi)  assistance  to  the  DDWSSD  and  ARIS  in 
improving their monitoring and evaluation (M&E) systems, as recommended by the program M&E 
assessment (including institutional arrangements; sex-disaggregated data collection, analysis, 
and reporting; and generation of more efficient national and regional reports through an improved 
web-based program performance management system); and (vii) related training. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
7.  The TA is estimated to cost $225,000, to be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. The 
government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff  and  national 
consultants under ARIS’s program implementation unit, office accommodation, office supplies, 
secretarial  assistance,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  government  was  informed  that 
approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
8.  The DDWSSD will be the executing agency for the TA, while ARIS will be the implementing 
agency  and  will  coordinate  with  the  DDWSSD.  ADB  will  be  responsible  for  facilitating 
implementation and supervision of the TA, including selection and supervision of consultants. The 
direct administration of these consulting services will enable ADB to provide timely and dedicated 
support to the DDWSSD and ARIS. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the 
table.

9.  Consulting  services.  ADB  will  engage  individual  consultants  following  the  ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions.3 The TA will provide 9 person-months (7 
person-months  of  international  specialists  and  2  person-months  of  national  specialists)  of 
consultant services to (i) assist the government with M&E of DLIs, other program results indicators, 
and PAP actions; and (ii) provide technical and procurement support to ARIS for effective program 
implementation. Where possible, use of output-based contracts and/or lump-sum costs provision 
for out-of-pocket expenses will be used for a simplified disbursement process (footnote 3).
